name: GJ 357
scenarioDescription:
The GJ 357 Exoplanetary System


Overview

GJ 357 is a star with 0.34 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.34 times its radius. It is located 30.79 light years away from the solar system.

GJ 357 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the GJ 357 system


GJ 357 b

GJ 357 b was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 357 b is 1.84122 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 357 b is 1.217 that of Earth. At 1.84122 Earth masses, GJ 357 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


GJ 357 c

GJ 357 c was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 357 c is 3.4025999999999996 times the mass of Earth. At 3.4025999999999996 Earth masses, GJ 357 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


GJ 357 d

GJ 357 d was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.20 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 357 d is 6.1024199999999995 times the mass of Earth. At 6.1024199999999995 Earth masses, GJ 357 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses. With a mass of 6.1024199999999995 Earth masses and a semi-major axis of 0.204 astronomical units, GJ 357 d could, potentially, be a habitable planet with stable bodies of liquid water on its surface, like Earth.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system GJ 357, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS).
